Review
Nanomaterials for products and application in agriculture, feed and food
Ruud J.B. Peters a, Hans Bouwmeester a, b, *, Stefania Gottardo c, Valeria Amenta c, 1, Maria Arena c, Puck Brandhoff a, Hans J.P. Marvin a, Agnieszka Mech c, Filipa Botelho Moniz c, Laia Quiros Pesudo c, Hubert Rauscher c, Reinhilde Schoonjans d, Anna K. Undas a, Maria Vittoria Vettori e, Stefan Weigel a, 2, Karin Aschberger c
a RIKILT- Wageningen UR, Wageningen, The Netherlands b Division of Toxicology, Wageningen University, Wageningen, The Netherlands c JRC- Nanobiosciences Unit, Institute for Health and Consumer Protection, Ispra, Italy d EFSA- Scientific Committee and Emerging Risks Unit, Parma, Italy e EFSA- Feed Unit, Parma, Italy

Keywords: Nanomaterial Food Feed Agriculture Application Products Risk assessment
* Corresponding author. RIKILT- Wageningen UR, W E-mail address: hans.bouwmeester@wur.nl (H. Bo

a b s t r a c t
Background: Nanotechnology applications can be found in agricultural production, animal feed, food processing, food additives and food contact materials (hereinafter referred to as agri/feed/food). A great diversity of nanomaterials is reported to be currently used in various applications, while new nanomaterials and applications are reported to be in development. Scope and approach: It is expected that applications of nanomaterials in agri/feed/food will increase in the future and thereby increase the human and environmental exposure to such materials. To gain up-todate knowledge we explored and reviewed the already marketed and in-development applications of nanomaterials in the agri/feed/food sectors upon the request of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). In this paper the results of the project are highlighted and discussed in more detail. Key findings and conclusions: The majority of the applications of nanomaterials that we identified concerned application in food as food additives and food contact materials, while much fewer applications seem to be developed for agriculture and feed. Nano-encapsulates, silver, titanium dioxide and silica are the most often mentioned nanomaterials in the literature. About half of the identified applications are claimed to be already in use. In-development applications are found for nano-encapsulates and nanocomposites in novel foods, food and feed additives, biocides, pesticides and food contact materials.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nanotechnology is one of the six key enabling technologies (KETs) for Europe (European Commission, 2016) as it offers substantial prospects for the development of innovative products and applications in several industrial sectors including the primary agricultural production, animal feed, food processing, novel foods, food additives and food contact materials (hereinafter referred to as
ageningen, The Netherlands. uwmeester). Data Sharing Unit, Helsinki,
essment, Berlin, Germany.
agri/feed/food) (Chaudhry et al., 2008; Joseph & Morrison, 2006; Kah, Beulke, Tiede, & Hofmann, 2013; Kah & Hofmann, 2014; Sekhon, 2010; Singh Sekhon, 2014). Countries and regions that fully exploit KETs will be at the forefront of creating advanced and sustainable economies. Nanotechnology involves working with manufacturing, characterisation and manipulation of materials which have a size range at the nanometer scale. Reduction of the size of the material to the nano scale may change the physicochemical properties compared to the same material at larger-size scales, e.g. much larger surface to mass ratio, enhanced surface reactivity or increased ion release.
Nanomaterials (NM) used in agri/feed/food may be of natural origin (i.e. naturally occurring/formed in the final product) or intentionally added. Intentionally added NM may be developed
using natural components or engineered components. Several formal definitions of the term “nanomaterial” have been proposed by different international and national bodies (European Commission, 2011a; ISO, 2010) and most of them aim to identify substances within a specific size range (reviewed by Amenta et al., 2015; L€ovestam et al., 2010; Rauscher et al., 2014). Notably, the only common feature between all NM is that they have at least one dimension in the nanoscale (L€ovestam et al., 2010). In the EU, engineered NM in food products have been defined as “any intentionally produced material that has one or more dimensions of the order of 100 nm or less or that is composed of discrete functional parts, either internally or at the surface, many of which have one or more dimensions of the order of 100 nm or less, including structures, agglomerates or aggregates, which may have a size above the order of

sections.heading: 100 nm but retain properties that are characteristic of the nanoscale”
sections.text:
(European Parliament and Council, 2015). In contrast, the European Commission's Recommendation on a definition of NM, which was drafted independently from any specific legislation and thus is broadly applicable across regulatory sectors, defines NM regardless of their origin and thereby includes also natural and incidental NM (European Commission, 2011a,b). The upper size limit of 100 nm used in most definitions is fairly arbitrary and does not directly correspond to any particular change in physico-chemical properties. Neither is there a direct link between this threshold and any potential increase in risk for human health or for the environment. Some countries (e.g. USA) therefore consider a definition based solely on size as inappropriate and have not introduced any legal definitions. Instead they have drafted flexible guidance to identify when potential implications should be considered for regulatory status, safety, effectiveness, or public health impact that may arise with the application of nanotechnology (FDA, 2011). This guidance also provides rules for certain chemical substances when they are manufactured or processed at the nanoscale (US-EPA, 2015).
Engineered NM used in agri/feed/food can roughly be divided into inorganic, organic and combined materials such as surface modified clays. Inorganic NM include metals, metal oxides, salts, full carbon-based materials such as carbon nanotubes, fullerenes, carbon black and clay (see Fig. 1). Some of these materials have been used in food-related applications for several decades, and consist of primary particles or contain fractions of particles in the nanosize range. Silicon dioxide, for example, has been used in food processing as anti-caking agent for years in a form called synthetic amorphous silica (SAS) and it is registered in the EU as food additive E551 (Peters et al., 2012). Some metals are available as nano-sized particles in food or health supplements. These include nanoselenium (Xu et al. 2007) and colloidal suspensions of e.g. gold, platinum and silver (Park, Li, & Kricka, 2006).
Food naturally contains nanostructured organic ingredients such as proteins, carbohydrates and fats, which usually selfassemble into higher-order structures. The same materials can
also serve to build food-grade polymers or nano-encapsulates and nano-emulsions (Graveland-Bikker & de Kruif, 2006; Luykx, Peters, Van Ruth, & Bouwmeester, 2008; Mozafari et al., 2006). Nanoencapsulates consist of an organic shell and a core containing the (bio)active ingredient. (Phospho-)Lipid-based NM, including micelles and liposomes, are among the most applied organic NM due to their wide solubility range (hydrophilic or lipophilic surface), i.e. they can be “tuned” to an application. Protein-based NM are often built from molecules capable of self-assembly, e.g. micelle-like structures. Polysaccharides are naturally occurring compounds in plants (e.g. pectin, guar gum), animals (e.g. chitosan, chondroitin sulphate), algae (e.g. alginates) and micro-organisms (e.g. dextran). Nano-encapsulation serves to increase the stability, delivery and bioavailability of nutrients (vitamins, minerals), agrochemicals or pharmaceuticals (Anu Puri et al., 2009). The modified optical characteristics of nano-encapsulated materials are important for their application in clear beverages. Inorganic NM such as clays are often surface modified (functionalised) with an organic coating to improve their dispersion in polymer matrices thus forming a nanocomposite (de Paiva, Morales, & Diaz, 2008). Modified nanoclays (e.g. montmorillonite) incorporated in food packaging enhance mechanical strength and/or form a barrier against gases (e.g. oxygen), volatile components (such as flavours) or moisture (Jorda-Beneyto et al., 2014). According to the revised European Novel Food Regulation (European Parliament and Council, 2015), these NM can be regarded as engineered NM and this should be taken into consideration when evaluating their prospective applications in agri/feed/food.
The potential risk that these newly applied NM in agri/food/feed products might pose to human health (and the environment) needs to be taken into account during the safety evaluation of such products. The work herein presented focussed on gaining more upto date information on the exposure potential to NM due to its application in agri/feed/food products. In particular, we explored, upon a request by the European Food Safety Authority, the currently used (i.e. already on the market) and in-development applications of NM in the agricultural, feed and food sectors. This included systematic bibliographic database searches and ad-hoc searches in the Internet and at company websites (initial and refined searches were performed between April and August 2013 and updated through a recent literature search in 2016 using the same search strategy) (the search strategy is provided as supplementary file 1). In addition, a questionnaire was sent to research institutes, government agencies and companies active in agri/feed/food (Peters et al., 2014).
This paper presents the overall trends, application domains, and diversity of NM applied in the agri/feed/food sector. This is followed by a more detailed description per application domain, complemented with examples. Finally the current claims for marketed nanoproducts and potential future developments are critically
applied in agriculture, feed and food sectors.
discussed.

sections.heading: 2. Nanomaterials application in agriculture, feed and food
2.1. Overall trends, application domains and diversity of NM utilised
sections.text:
An assessment of the collected data from our literature search showed that more than two thirds of the identified applications concern use in food (88%) while a small percentage of applications targeted agriculture (9%) and feed (3%). About half of the applications were claimed to be already used in a (consumer) product therefore available on the market, while about one fifth of the applications were clearly in the research and development stage and may become marketable in the future.
Inorganic NM are the NM types most frequently mentioned as used in agri/feed/food. About half of the applications use inorganic NM including metals (29%), metal oxides (26%), full-carbon based materials (6%, mostly carbon nanotubes and a few fullerenes and carbon black) and clay (6%). Nanocomposites (7%) are mostly (bio) polymers containing clay, also called surface-modified clay. Another large part of records concern applications of nanoencapsulates (26%), being described as nanocapsules, nanocarriers, nano-emulsions or micelles. Focussing on NM types reveals that 80% of the NM are mentioned less than 10 times and that 50% of those, e.g. gold, are mentioned only once. This indicates that a few types of NM form the majority NM applied in this domain, with nano-encapsulates, silver, titanium dioxide and silica (SAS and silicon dioxide) as the most prominent ones (Fig. 2).
Most of the studies analysed for this review focussed on the application in products. Fig. 3 gives an overview of the most important physicochemical characteristics reported in the papers
assessed in the current study. The size range or average particle size of the NM is most often reported, while only in a minority of the
ypes of NM represent about 75% of the identified applications. Exact numbers can be
studies other important physicochemical characteristics such as shape, zeta potential, aggregation state and size distribution are described. There is thus a lack of systematic reporting of physicochemical properties of NM applied in products.

sections.heading: 2.2. Applications in agricultural production
sections.text: During agricultural production nano-formulated pesticides and other nano-formulated agro-chemicals are employed to increase the efficacy compared to conventional formulations (Gogos, Knauer, & Bucheli, 2012; Joseph & Morrison, 2006; Kah, 2015; Kah et al., 2013; Sarkar et al., 2015). This can be achieved by reducing the size of active ingredients and other compounds to the nanorange, mixing them into nano-emulsions or nano-dispersions or by incorporating them in solid lipid or polymeric nano-capsules (Frederiksen, Kristensen, & Pedersen, 2003). Nanoencapsulates based on chitosan, a chitin derived polysaccharide, have been studied for a variety of agro-chemicals (Kashyap, Xiang, & Heiden, 2015). Solid lipid and polymeric nano-capsules loaded with carbendazim and tebuconazole have been explored as a novel fungicide formulation. The reported results showed a high loading capacity of the nano-capsules with a gradual release of the fungicides and decreased (adverse) effect on plant growth compared to current commercial products (Campos et al., 2015). Porous hollow silica has been evaluated for controlled release of the pesticide validamycin and the herbicide 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetate (Liu et al., 2006). Surfactant based nano-emulsions have been evaluated as a delivery system for the pesticide beta-cypermethrin (Wang, Li, Zhang, Dong, & Eastoe, 2007). Nano-gels containing the pheromonemethyl eugenol proved to be a low cost approach to control fruit pests, due to lower applied doses without losing efficacy (Bhagat, Samanta, & Bhattacharya, 2013). Naturally occurring nanosized ashes and inorganic metal nanoparticles have been studied for insecticidal, antimicrobial or antifungal properties (Sonkar, Roy, Babar, & Sarkar, 2012; Stadler, Buteler, & Weaver, 2010; Yildiz & Pala, 2012). Nanoparticles coated with polyethylene-glycol and loaded with garlic essential oils have been studied to control stored-product pests (Yang, Li, Zhu, & Lei, 2009). In addition to protecting crops and food products from pests, nanotechnology can also boost crop production and quality (Kole et al., 2013; Mondal, Basu, Das, & Nandy, 2011; Wang, Ma, Zhang, Pei, & Chen, 2012) and thereby potentially reduce the quantity of fertiliser applied (Pandey, Sanjay, & Yadav, 2010). The presence of NM in soil may also affect the root nutrient uptake and water transport (Martínez-Fern andez, Barroso, & Kom arek, 2016).

sections.heading: 2.3. Applications in feed
sections.text:
Only a limited number of NM applications as feed additive, which appear to be in the development phase, were identified. In addition, no information was found that certain food additives, e.g. encapsulated vitamins or nutrients, would be used also as feed additives. However, NM are being developed and tested for efficacy to replace antibiotics by absorbing bacteria and toxins, and to improve the digestibility of feed. Antibacterial nanosilver, for example, is claimed to have an effect similar to conventional antibiotics and is being added to drinking water for chickens (Pineda et al., 2012) and pigs (Fondevila, Herrer, Casallas, Abecia, & Ducha, 2009). Nanosilver has also been tested to reduce the toxicity of aflatoxin in chickens (Gholami-Ahangaran & ZiaJahromi, 2013). The contamination of animal feed with mycotoxins represents a worldwide problem for farmers and can cause serious diseases in farm animals. Nanoclays (e.g. montmorillonite based nanoclays) and other nanoparticles (e.g. polystyrene-based particles) have been shown to specifically absorb mycotoxins in
the gastrointestinal tract of animals and to protect them from mycotoxosis (Kuzma, Romanchek, & Kokotovich, 2008; Shi, Xu, Feng, & Wang, 2006). Size-reduction of materials to the nanorange can also increase the absorption of nutrients as shown for iron (Mahler et al., 2012) and selenium which significantly improved the feed digestion in sheep (Xun et al., 2012). Similarly, nano-forms of selenium have been explored as novel formulated micronutrient and the nano-forms are claimed to have an increased bioavailability in fish (Sarkar et al., 2015) and livestock (Selim, Radwan, Youssef, Salah Eldin, & Abo Elwafa, 2015). While not being a feed application, injecting copper nanoparticles or copper sulphate in chicken eggs improved the feed conversion rate by increasing the muscles at the end of the rearing period and lowering the mortality (Mroczek-Sosnowska et al., 2015). Lastly, bio-conjugated nanoparticles (encapsulation) have been evaluated for the slow release of nutrients or active compounds used in feed and veterinary drugs (Verma, Singh, & Vikas, 2012; Xun et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Applications in food additives and food supplements
sections.text:
Most nanotechnology applications in food production involve food additives which are used to improve the stability of foods during processing and storage, to enhance product characteristics, or to increase the potency and bioavailability of nutrients in the food. A number of such food additives have been identified in the literature, with the most common one being synthetic amorphous silica (SAS). The most frequently used SAS is produced either as precipitated or fumed silica and is composed of aggregates of primary particles in the lower nanometre size range. SAS is used as clarifying agent for beverages, and as a free-flow and anti-caking agent in many powdered food items (E551). At least a part of the silica material in powdered food items is in the nano-size range (Dekkers et al., 2011). Beside SAS, other manufactured anti-caking agents are used in food products, including calcium silicate, sodium aluminosilicate, dicalcium phosphate, sodium ferrocyanide and microcrystalline cellulose. There is no information in the searched literature whether these materials are (partly) at the nanoscale.
Another important food additive is titanium dioxide (E171). Titanium dioxide is used as a pigment to enhance the white colour of certain foods, such as dairy products and candy (Weir, Westerhoff, Fabricius, Hristovski,& Von Goetz, 2012). The whitening TiO2 is not a new material it may however contain a fraction of nano-sized particles arising from the production process (Peters et al., 2014). In this situation it should be transparently clarified if this nanofraction is included and available in the final product. TiO2 is also used as a food additive and flavour enhancer in a variety of nonwhite foods, including dried vegetables, nuts, seeds, soups, and mustard, as well as beer and wine. Dietary intake of titanium dioxide in foods is of increasing interest and a recent study showed that 5e36% of the titanium dioxide in common food products was found in the nano-size range (Weir et al., 2012). Titanium dioxide in nanoform is used as antimicrobial agent, sometimes in combination with other compounds or elements as nickel oxide and cobalt, for the inactivation of foodborne pathogens (Amna et al., 2013). EFSA has re-evaluated the safety of E171 used as a food additive and in feed (EFSA, 2016).
Iron in the form of iron oxide is mostly used as a food colorant. Although there is no information about the size of these particles in the searched literature, they are likely to be in the micron-size range since they are produced by grinding larger particles. Iron nanoparticles are being studied as a health-promoting food additive since iron deficiency is one of the most commonmicronutrient
deficiencies worldwide. The solubility and the bioavailability of poorly acid-soluble iron compounds can be improved by decreasing their primary particle size and thereby increasing their specific surface area. Nanostructured iron containing compounds may prove useful for iron fortification of certain foods (Zimmermann & Hilty, 2011).
While the additives discussed above are being added to improve the food product itself or to maintain the palatability of a product, nano delivery systems are employed to increase the bio-availability of nutrients to the consumer. Nano-encapsulation involves the incorporation, absorption or dispersion of bioactive compounds in or on nano-sized vesicles, and this may protect the bioactive compounds against degradation, improve stability and solubility (e.g. solubilizing a hydrophilic compound in hydrophobic matrices and vice versa) leading to increased bioavailability and delivery to cells and tissues (McClements, 2010; Taylor, Davidson, Bruce, & Weiss, 2005). There is a relative large number of nano-encapsulated NM available and used in products with sizes ranging from the micro to the nano-range, as recently described in several studies and reviews (Dickinson, 2015; Dur an & Marcato, 2012; Ezhilarasi, Karthik, Chhanwal, & Anandharamakrishnan, 2013; Kim, Park, & Lim, 2015; Kuan, Yee-Fung, Yuen, & Liong, 2012; McClements, 2011; McClements & Rao, 2011; Rodriguez-Amaya, 2016). Micelles are used to improve the solubility of bio-actives such as vitamin A, C, D, E and K, coenzyme Q10, b-carotene, isoflavones, a-lipoic acid and omega-3 fatty acids (AquaNova; Aslani et al., 2014; Chow, Gue, Leow, & Goh, 2015; Gokmen et al., 2011). LycoVit™, a gelatine based nanoparticulate material containing synthetic lycopene has been shown to increase the bioavailability of the carotenoid lycopene in comparison to lycopene from fresh, non-processed tomatoes (Hoppe, Kramer, van den Berg, Steenge, & van Vliet, 2003). MicroHydrin™, which is used as an antioxidant dietary supplement (Health&LightInstitute) is claimed to consist of molecular cages, 1e5 nm in diameter, made from a silica-mineral hydride complex (Health_&_Light_Institute). The same company also produces Artichoke Nanoclusters and Slim Shake Chocolate, both based on coated nano-size silica particles that carry the flavour.
Empty liposomes are also available on the market to form encapsulation micelles. An example is nanocapsules marketed under the name Coatsome™, a phospholipid-based micelle mainly intended for research studies, consisting of cholesterol, L-(a)dipalmitoylphosphatidylglycerol (DPPG), and L-(a)-dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) that spontaneously form liposome micelles upon suspension in water (Coatsome). Most encapsulates are organic NM, and thus a special case is the use of nano-sized silicon to improve the stability of hydrophobic nutrients during processing and storage through a combined effect of nanostructuring and solid state modification (Canham, 2007). Phytoglycogen octenyl succinate, an amphiphilic carbohydrate nanoparticle loaded with ε-polylysine, has shown to improve the shelf life of lipid products by avoiding oxidation (Scheffler, Wang, Huang, Gonzalez, & Yao, 2010). The antimicrobial capacity of encapsulated nisin, a polycyclic antibacterial peptide, in skimmed milk inoculated with Listeria and in cheese was compared to free nisin. At higher temperatures free nisin in milk showed better inhibitory properties; however, in milk and cheese at lower temperatures (refrigeration) encapsulated nisin showed better results (da Silva Malheiros, Daroit, da Silveira, & Brandelli, 2010; Imran et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Applications in food contact materials
sections.text:
NM and nanotechnology may be employed in different materials that come into contact with food. These applications include
food packaging, storing boxes, cooking equipment, crockery, coatings of machines and surfaces, or nano-sieves/membranes.
The most important type of nanotechnology application in the food area for the near future is considered the incorporation of NM in packaging materials or storage containers in order to increase the storage time while keeping the products fresh (Donatella, Clara, Marilena, Sossio, & Antonella, 2013; Manikantan & Varadharaju, 2011; Ramachandraiah, Han, & Chin, 2015; Silvestre & Cimmino, 2013). So-called nano-composites serve to reduce the permeability of the food packaging materials to atmospheric oxygen, moisture or carbon dioxide (Silvestre & Cimmino, 2013). They are thermoplastic polymers that have nanoscale inclusions, mostly consisting of nanoclays, 2e8% by weight, added to polypropylene-based nanocomposite or polyamide plastic films (e.g. Durethan® for meat-packaging) (Brody, Bugusu, Han, Sand, & McHugh, 2008). Other examples of fillers include carbon nanotubes and nanoforms of metal and metal oxide, cellulose or polymeric resins and fibres (Ramachandraiah et al., 2015; Shatkin & Kim, 2015; Singla, Mehta, & Upadhyay, 2012). The added benefit of nanoclays is an improvement in tensile strength and thermal properties and therefore polymer-clay nano-composites have emerged as novel food packaging material. Materials consisting of polyamide layered with silicate barriers have additional properties such as thermal buffering (Johnston, Grindrod, Dodds, & Schimitschek, 2008). In low-density polyethylene films, hybridisation of nanoclays contributed to slow down the out-diffusion and thus maintain higher contents of antibacterial and antifungal essential oils (Shemesh et al., 2015). Nanocomposite films enriched with silicate nanoparticles or nanocrystals exhibiting increased barrier properties can be used for plastic beer bottles (e.g. Nanocor®) (Nanocor, 2016) which have been reported in the US, but so far not in the EU. Natural biopolymer-based nanocomposite packaging materials with bio-functional properties include chitosan, cellulose and carrageenan (Rhim, Park, & Ha, 2013; SanchezGarcia, Lopez-Rubio, & Lagaron, 2010; Shatkin & Kim, 2015; Yang, Dominici, Fortunati, Kenny, & Puglia, 2015). Carbon nanotubes can be used in food packaging to improve mechanical properties and introduce antimicrobial effects (Rungraeng, Cho, Yoon, & Jun, 2012). NM incorporated in biodegradable food packaging, for example AgeTiO2 nanoparticles in biodegradable polylactide (PLA) composite films, demonstrated to improve the thermal, mechanical and barrier properties while at the same time they increased the photodegradability of the packaging material due to absorption of ultraviolet radiation (Pillai, Ray, Scriba, Ojijo, & Hato, 2013). In addition, phase change materials incorporated into nano and micro sized polycaprolactone, polylactic or polystyrene beads contribute to increasing the thermal buffer capacities of the food packaging systems and allowed a better preservation of the cold chain (P erez-Masi a, L opez-Rubio, Fabra, & Lagaron, 2014).
The most common NM added to food packaging to confer antimicrobial properties are silver, chitosan, zinc oxide (Li, Li, Zhang, & Xing, 2011), TiO2 (Yemmireddy, Farrell, & Hung, 2015) and nisin (de Azeredo, 2013; Ravishankar Rai & Jamuna Bai, 2011; Trbojevich & Fern andez, 2015). Chitosan is a very promising option for antimicrobial food packaging, and has great potential for a wide range of applications due to its biodegradability, biocompatibility, antimicrobial activity, non-toxicity and versatile chemical and physical properties (Aresta et al., 2013; Dutta, Tripathi, Mehrotra, & Dutta, 2009). Due to its strong photocatalytic activity under UV irradiation nanostructured titanium dioxide has been suggested to be effective in eliminating pathogenicmicroorganisms in food contact surfaces and thereby enhancing food safety (Ravishankar Rai & Jamuna Bai, 2011; Yemmireddy et al., 2015).
Zinc oxide NM has also been shown to effectively protect products from foodborne pathogens (Espitia et al., 2012; Li et al., 2011; Sinha, Gadhwal, Joshi, SrivaStava, & Govil, 2011). A combination of zinc oxide and copper oxide NM is interesting for applications in the food industry as they have a selective toxicity towards bacteria and only induce minimal effects on human health (Ravishankar Rai & Jamuna Bai, 2011). At present, silver is the most investigated antibacterial nanoparticle due to its biocidal activity against a broad range of Gram-positive and Gram-negative microorganisms, yeast, moulds and viruses. The antimicrobial activity is mainly based on the release of Agþ ions which bind to electron donor groups in molecules containing sulphur, oxygen or nitrogen. Bactericidal properties are size dependent; they increase with decreasing size and increasing surface area (Jose Ruben et al., 2005). Silver nanoparticles can be added to food packaging materials in several ways, for instance as finely dispersed nanosilver particles embedded in containers and coatings (Llorens, Lloret, Picouet, Trbojevich, & Fernandez, 2012; Popov, Hinkov, Diankov, Karsheva, & Handzhiyski, 2015), as a silver-based zeolite in polylactic acid biocomposites (Busolo, Fernandez, Ocio, & Lagaron, 2010), or as gelatine-silver nano-composites (Halder, Mitra, Bag, Raychaudhuri, & Chakraborty, 2011). Some products containing silver-modified inorganic carriers are commercialised for food contact materials, e.g. Agion®, Bactiblock®, Novaron®, Zeomic® (Trbojevich & Fern andez, 2015). In the EU (nano) silver is not approved for use in plastic materials and articles intended to come into contact with food (European Commission, 2011c).
Beside the application of NM as antimicrobial agents other promising applications for food packaging include oxygen scavengers, ethylene removers and carbon dioxide absorbers/emitters (Silvestre, Duraccio, & Cimmino, 2011). Polymers in conjunction with nanodevices such as nanosensors are referred to as smart packaging. They can be used to monitor food for the presence of microbes, toxins and chemicals, thereby delivering a real time status of the food quality (Silvestre et al., 2011). Nanosensors based on TiO2 or metal nanoparticles, or nanocrystalline SnO2 can serve as indicators for O2, gases, pH changes or the formation of metabolites due to microbiological growth, mostly by triggering a colour change.
Nanosieves and nanomembranes are employed to remove undesired products from food, e.g. to filter out bacteria. Nano/micro porous cellulose-based filter material packed in a bioreactor was tested to remove microbial contamination from apple juice aiming to replace industrial pasteurization techniques (Gialleli, Bekatorou, Kanellaki, Nigam, & Koutinas, 2015). In milk processing plants graphene oxide nanoplates were shown to mitigate membrane fouling in membrane bioreactors of wastewater treatment (Zinadini et al., 2015). While, researching fresh food product conservation techniques (Chee, Shafel, Park, & Jun, 2015), developed a photothermal (“‘nanotherapy”) heating technique which focuses on microbes conjugated with gold NM (1.4e20 nm) labelled antibodies; the potential contamination of the treated products with gold NM was not investigated (Chee et al., 2015).
Improved and active nanoenabled packaging are reported to be mainly used in the Asia/Pacific area (45% of the current market), as well as in the USA and Australia (Silvestre et al., 2011). In the EU industrial applications are slowly coming. The following nanoforms have been authorised for use in food contact materials: titanium nitride, silicon dioxide, carbon black, (butadiene, ethyl acrylate, methyl methacrylate, styrene) copolymer in nanoform cross-linked with divinylbenzene, cross-linked with 1,3-butanediol dimethacrylate or not cross-linked, and kaolin (EFSA, 2016) (European Commission, 2011c). For these materials no migration of the NM to the food was demonstrated and the risk assessment was based on zero exposure. More applications are under evaluation (EFSA,
2016b).

sections.heading: 3. Future trends
sections.text:
Research into new products and applications of NM in agri/feed/ food continues to increase in number and variety. The majority of the applications of NM identified in our search concerned application in food (i.e. food additives) and food contact materials, while a much smaller number of applications seem to be developed for agriculture and feed. Nano-encapsulates, silver, silica and titanium dioxide are the most often mentioned NM in the literature. About half of the identified applications are claimed to be placed on the market and in use.
In agricultural production, nano-formulated agro-chemicals (pesticides) are developed based on an expected increased efficacy compared to conventional formulations. Notwithstanding the great prospects that nanotechnology may offer to improve plant fertilization products (DeRosa, Monreal, Schnitzer, Walsh, & Sultan, 2010) only few patents for such products have been identified so far (Peters et al., 2014). In contrast, several companies, such as Syngenta, Bayer, Monsanto, Sumitomo, BASF, and Dow Agrosciences, have deposited patents comprising a wide range of protocols for production and application of encapsulated formulations, which can be used to produce nanopesticides (Perlatti et al., 2012). On the websites of these companies no advertisement of “nanoproducts” can be found (yet). Some nano-products are already being marketed in some regions (mainly USA), like e.g. Nanocid® based pesticides (Gholami-Ahangaran & Zia-Jahromi, 2013) and Chitosan (Cota-Arriola, Onofre Cortez-Rocha, Burgos-Hern andez, Marina Ezquerra-Brauer, & Plascencia-Jatomea, 2013). In the EU only some nano-products have been reported in formulations (EFSA, 2016). Thus, it is expected that nano-agrochemicals, soon to emerge on the market, would not be based on new active nanoingredients, but would mostly consist of nano-emulsions/ dispersions of already registered active ingredients.
A size reduction of the active ingredient to the nanoscale or generation of nano-emulsions/dispersions are also likely to have an impact on the environmental fate and behaviour of the pesticides and other agrochemicals (Kah & Hofmann, 2014). Solvents and surfactants required to introduce and preserve “nano-emulsions” may impact on the fate of agrochemicals or have a direct impact on soil sorption. Higher residue levels of pesticides in the crop and increased/prolonged exposure of non-target organisms may result from slow release of active ingredients. The risk assessment of nanopesticides and other nano-agrochemicals thus needs to take into account the different properties and behaviour of the NM and of the formulation.
The main exploitation of NM applications in animal feed addresses the increased bioavailability of micronutrients (i.e. selenium) and provides a way to manage undesirable high levels of mycotoxins. Although it can be expected that some food processing agents may also be applied in feed production (Chaudhry et al., 2008), we did not find any study specifically focusing on such an application. Bulk-TiO2 which may also contain a fraction in the nano-sized range has been re-evaluated in the EU as feed- and food-additive (EFSA, 2016).
Clearly, most in-development applications of NM are found in the domains of (novel) foods, additives and food contact materials. Micro and nano encapsulates loaded with an active ingredient are an important development for food additives. They can be used to increase the shelf-life of products, as well as to improve bioavailability of bioactive compounds. While technical hurdles remain challenging, also the safety of these applications needs to be demonstrated. A major issue for the safety of these materials is the increased bioavailability and modified biokinetics due to different
size. Various other factors such as food matrix, biochemical and metabolic factors and individual characteristics may however also influence the behaviour. The safety assessment needs to consider the influence of the food matrix and modifications in the gastrointestinal tract of engineered nanoscale food ingredients (Cockburn et al., 2012; EFSA, 2011; Szakal et al., 2014). The most frequently mentioned nano food additives, such as silica or TiO2, are not new materials and are not intentionally produced as NM because of new “nanoproperties”. They may contain however a fraction of nanosized particles arising from the production process. Current reevaluation of food-additives by EFSA includes an assessment whether such materials would be considered NM according to the regulatory definition and whether there are concerns for human health (European Commission., 2010).
There are many promising applications for NM in food contact materials to improve thermal, mechanical, barrier and antimicrobial properties. Only few substances in nano-form have made it so far to commercial applications, especially in the EU. The main reasons for this may be legislative hurdles and uncertainty about the efficacy and the economic and environmental impact that such systems may have. For food contact materials, the proff of the absence of exposure e.g. by showing no migration into the food matrix from the packaging material may facilitate their regulatory and consumer acceptance.
The introduction of nanotechnology in agri/feed/food applications is affected by several factors including technological feasibility, cost effectiveness, regulatory requirements and consumer acceptance. Recent studies suggest that the public perception is not negative towards an introduction of nanotechnology in agriculture, if the benefit to the consumer is clear (Parisi, Vigani, & RodríguezCerezo, 2015). Consumer acceptance has shown to be higher for nanotechnology in the development of novel packaging with distinct benefits rather when integrated directly in food (Giles, Kuznesof, Clark, Hubbard, & Frewer, 2015) (Gupta, Fischer, & Frewer, 2015).
Application of NM and nanotechnology in agri/feed/food may only enter the market after regulatory approval. Applicants need to demonstrate the safety of new products for the consumer and for the environment (Amenta et al., 2015; Bouwmeester et al., 2009; Martirosyan & Schneider, 2014). Dedicated studies are required to indicate the safety of products containing NM. This includes the application of test methods which are specifically developed for NM or explicitly demonstrated to be are suitable for NM.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
This study presents an overview of marketed and indevelopment applications of NM in the agriculture, feed and food sectors. Information came from several sources including an extensive and structured literature search and additional ad-hoc literature searches, company websites, and a questionnaire sent to NM experts, producers and developers. The current and planned applications use a variety of inorganic NM, including metals, metal oxides, clay and full-carbon materials, and organic NM where the vast majority consists of nano-encapsulates and nano-composites. Nano-encapsulates, silver and titanium dioxide are the most reported NM in the agri/feed/food application area. Use as food additive, as supplement, or in and food contact material are the NM applications most frequently indicated. In the agricultural sector several nano-pesticides and nano-fertilisers are in development but only few are already marketed. In the feed sector only a limited number of NM are in development to be used as feed additives. Applications in novel foods, biocides and pesticides are currently
mostly in the development stage. A comparison between marketed and in-development applications indicates a trend moving from inorganic to organic NM. The identified products and application fields confirm that nanotechnology can be regarded as an enabling technology. Product description and clarity regarding the exact function of a NM in a certain product, as well as market status can however be improved.

sections.text: We thank Teodor Ivanov and Aris Tsois (JRC Ispra) for their contributions. The information on the current and future use of NM in the agricultural, feed and food sector were produced as part of EFSA contract CFT/EFSA/FEED/2012/01, “Inventory of Nanotechnology applications in the agricultural, feed and food sector”. While not being a feed application, injecting copper nanoparticles or copper sulphate in chicken eggs improved the feed conversion rate by increasing the muscles at the end of the rearing period and lowering the mortality (Mroczek-Sosnowska et al., 2015).

Lastly, bio-conjugated nanoparticles (encapsulation) have been evaluated for the slow release of nutrients or active compounds used in feed and veterinary drugs (Verma, Singh, & Vikas, 2012; Xun et al., 2012).

metadata.abstractText: Background: Nanotechnology applications can be found in agricultural production, animal feed, food processing, food additives and food contact materials (hereinafter referred to as agri/feed/food). A great diversity of nanomaterials is reported to be currently used in various applications, while new nanomaterials and applications are reported to be in development. Scope and approach: It is expected that applications of nanomaterials in agri/feed/food will increase in the future and thereby increase the human and environmental exposure to such materials. To gain up-todate knowledge we explored and reviewed the already marketed and in-development applications of nanomaterials in the agri/feed/food sectors upon the request of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). In this paper the results of the project are highlighted and discussed in more detail. Key findings and conclusions: The majority of the applications of nanomaterials that we identified concerned application in food as food additives and food contact materials, while much fewer applications seem to be developed for agriculture and feed. Nano-encapsulates, silver, titanium dioxide and silica are the most often mentioned nanomaterials in the literature. About half of the identified applications are claimed to be already in use. In-development applications are found for nano-encapsulates and nanocomposites in novel foods, food and feed additives, biocides, pesticides and food contact materials. © 2016 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
